questions.text: A patient presents with the Tense bullous lesions associated with itching. Histopathology revealed Subepidermal blistering. What is the diagnosis of this condition & what are the antigens against which autoantibodies are most commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bullous Pemphigoid & BP180

 

Option A.

 

  • Bullous pemphigoid is a subepidermal vesiculobullous disorder where there is at the dermo-epidermal junction (DEJ).
  • Tense bullae which are associated with itching are suggestive of bullous pemphigoid. The bullae are Nikolsky negative as acantholysis is absent.
  • Autoantibodies against BP180 are most commonly seen in this condition.

 

BP180 is also known as BPAg2, and it is seen in 75-90% of bullous pemphigoid patients. Autoantibodies against BP230or BPAg1 are recognized in 50-70% of bullous pemphigoid patients.

 

 

Histopathology of Bullous Pemphigoid showing Subepidermal split:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris & Desmoglein 3.

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is associated with flaccid blisters, not tense ones, and the blisters are intraepidermal due to acantholysis.
  • The main autoantigen is Desmoglein 3, a desmosomal protein.

 

Option C. Bullous Pemphigoid & BP280.

 

  • This option is incorrect because BP280 (collagen type VII) is not the primary

antigen in Bullous Pemphigoid; BP180 is the correct antigen.

 

Option D. Pemphigus vulgaris & Desmoglein 1.

 

  • While Desmoglein 1 is indeed a target antigen in some cases of Pemphigus vulgaris (usually in combination with Desmoglein 3), the description provided does not match Pemphigus vulgaris, which presents with supra basal intra-epidermal blistering and flaccid bullae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with tense bullae and histopathology showing subepidermal blistering, the diagnosis is Bullous Pemphigoid, and the autoantibodies are most commonly directed against the BP180 antigen.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.10

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with fragile skin arrives at the Dermatology OPD. On examination, it was observed that he has bullae which are healing with scarring, and erosions on the extensor surfaces of his elbows, hands, and knees. DIF findings revealed antibodies against type VII collagen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita

 

Option B.

 

  • Direct immunofluorescence microscopy showing antibodies against type VII collagen is suggestive of Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita (EBA).

    NOTE: Why it is NOT Epidermolysis Bullosa Dystrophica (Dystrophic EB):

  • Some students may confuse Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita with Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa (DEB) because both involve type VII collagen and show scarring bullae. However, key differences are:

     

  • Dystrophic EB is a genetic (inherited) disorder, often presenting in infancy or childhood, not in a 52-year-old adult.
  • DIF in Dystrophic EB is negative, because it is not immune-mediated, unlike EBA.
  • EBA is acquired and shows positive DIF due to autoantibodies against type VII collagen.

 

 

Image depicting structure of DEJ / BMZ

 

 

 

  • Epiderm­­olysis Bullosa Acquisita (EBA): It is an acquired autoimmune disorder, presenting in adults between 44-54 years. It has a chronic, relapsing course.

  • Direct immunofluorescence microscopy is positive due to the presence of antibodies against type VII collagen.

  • DIF is negative in the below given Genetic conditions, as there are NO antibodies in these diseases.

 

EB = Epidermolysis Bullosa

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epidermolysis bullosa simplex

  • It is a condition characterized by skin fragility and blistering, but it is due to mutations affecting keratins in the epidermis, not autoantibodies against type VII collagen.

 

Option C. Hailey-Hailey disease also known as familial benign pemphigus

  • It is a genetic disorder that results in a blistering skin condition but does not involve autoantibodies against type VII collagen.

 

Option D. Darier's Disease

  • It is a genetic disorder characterized by greasy, warty papules and plaques, particularly in seborrheic areas, not by bullae that heal with scarring, and it is not associated with antibodies against type VII collagen.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient presenting with fragile skin, scarring bullae on extensor surfaces, and DIF findings showing antibodies against type VII collagen, the most likely diagnosis is Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.

 

Ref: Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.41

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl child presents to OPD with blisters over perioral area & other periorificial areas which are arranged annularly giving a ‘crown of jewels’ appearance (Image given below). Direct immunofluorescence microscopy revealed linear IgA deposition in Basement membrane zone. What is the most likely diagnosis & what is the drug of choice in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic Bullous Disease of Childhood & Dapsone

 

Option C.

 

  • The given image showing blisters over perioral area & other periorificial areas in an annular fashion giving a ‘crown of jewels’ appearance with linear deposition of IgA at the dermo-epidermal junction is diagnostic for linear IgA disease (LABD) or chronic bullous disorder of childhood (CBDC) or IgA pemphigoid.

 

 

  • It is the most common immunobullous disease in infants and children.
  • It has Bimodal age group distribution, i.e., it may occur <5 years or at 60-65 years of age.
  • It occurs in genetically susceptible individuals and can be triggered by drugs like vancomycin, penicillin, and NSAIDs.

 

Management:

 

  • While dapsone is primarily a bactericidal drug, it also has an anti-inflammatory action by decreasing the action of neutrophil enzymes. Hence, it is useful in the treatment of IgA pemphigoid.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid

 

  • It is typically a disease of the elderly and is characterized by subepidermal blisters with linear IgG and C3 deposition, not IgA.
  • Dapsone is not the first-line treatment for bullous pemphigoid.

 

Option B. Chronic bullous disease of childhood (CBDC), also known as linear IgA disease.

 

  • It is the correct diagnosis based on the description, but azathioprine is not the drug of choice.
  • It is used as a second-line or adjunctive therapy when dapsone is contraindicated or insufficient.

 

Option D. Epidermolysis bullosa simplex

 

  • It is a hereditary condition characterized by skin fragility and blistering due to cytoskeletal protein mutations.
  • Genetic counselling may be of value for familial planning, but the condition does not present with linear IgA deposition, nor is it treated with dapsone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a child presenting with annularly arranged periorificial blisters and linear IgA deposition at the basement membrane zone, the most likely diagnosis is Chronic bullous disease of childhood, and the drug of choice is dapsone.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page N50.33

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements about Bullous Pemphigoid EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral Erosions are frequently seen

 

Option B.

 

  • In Bullous Pemphigoid Oral erosions are an uncommon occurrence (NOT frequently seen).
  • The Asboe-Hansen sign is when a blister extends to nearby, unblistered skin after pressure is applied over the bulla.
  • In Bullous Pemphigoid, it is positive.
  • Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune disease of the elderly, between 70 to 80 years.
  • Bullae, which are primarily found on the flexural aspects of limbs and the abdomen, are tense and extremely itchy.
  • Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by linear IgG deposits on direct immunofluorescence (DIF) microscopy as seen in the below image.

 

 

Oral erosions are an uncommon occurrence (NOT frequently seen).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Asboe-Hansen sign may be positive in Bullous Pemphigoid.

 

  • It is also known as the "blister spread sign," indicating that gentle pressure on the top of an intact blister may cause it to extend into adjacent unblistered skin.

 

Option C. Direct immunofluorescence

 

  • In Bullous Pemphigoid typically shows linear IgG and often C3 deposits along the basement membrane zone, which is consistent with a subepidermal blistering process.

 

Option D. Acantholysis

 

  • Refers to the loss of keratinocyte-to-keratinocyte adhesion within the epidermis, is not a feature of Bullous Pemphigoid. This disorder is characterized by a subepidermal split without acantholysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bullous Pemphigoid may show a positive Asboe-Hansen sign and will have linear IgG deposition on DIF, but oral erosions are not a frequent finding, and acantholysis is absent as it is a subepidermal disorder.

 

Ref:Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.10- 50.15

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient complains of the following intensely itchy rash over her elbows, knees as shown in the image below. She is also a known case of celiac disease & she strictly follows a gluten-free diet, which has resulted in improvement of her diarrhea. However, the following itchy skin lesions have persisted despite her altered diet. What is the Drug of choice for this patient & what is the characteristic DIF finding seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapsone & Granular Deposits of IgA in Dermal Papillae

 

Option A.

 

  • Dapsone is the drug of choice for dermatitis herpetiformis and can provide rapid relief of itching. The characteristic DIF finding in dermatitis herpetiformis is granular deposits of IgA in the dermal papillae.
  • The image and history presented suggest a dermatological condition associated with celiac disease.
  • Given the intense itching, the locations over elbows and knees, and the association with celiac disease, the most likely diagnosis is dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Steroids & Linear deposits of IgA in Basement membrane Zone.

 

  • While steroids may be used in a variety of dermatological conditions, they are not the first-line treatment for dermatitis herpetiformis.
  • Additionally, linear deposits of IgA at the basement membrane zone are indicative of a different condition, such as linear IgA disease.

 

Option C. Dapsone& Granular deposits of IgG in dermal papillae.

 

  • Although Dapsone is the correct treatment, the characteristic DIF finding in dermatitis herpetiformis is granular IgA, not IgG deposits.

 

Option D.Steroids & Linear deposits of IgG in Basement membrane Zone.

 

  • This option suggests a diagnosis of Bullous pemphigoid and does not correspond to dermatitis herpetiformis, which is characterized by IgA deposits.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient with an intensely itchy rash over the elbows and knees and a history of celiac disease, the drug of choice is Dapsone, and the characteristic DIF finding is granular deposits of IgA in the dermal papillae.

 

Ref:Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.52-50.54

choices.text: Mutation of the ATP2A2 gene seen
Corps Ronds & Grains seen in Histopathology
Tense Bullae seen over Flexors
﻿DIF will be Negative

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements about Darier’s disease EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tense Bullae seen over Flexors

 

Option C.

 

Dariers disease / Keratosis follicularis:

 

  • Though categorised under VBDs, Dariers disease / Keratosis follicularis patients does not present with Vesicles or bullous lesions.
  • Darier's disease is an autosomal dominant condition that occurs due to dysfunction of the SERCA2 calcium channel (encoded by ATP2A2 gene), which is essential for desmosomal function. Dysfunction of SERCA2 results in acantholysis and dyskeratosis.

 

Clinical Features:

 

Discrete or confluent rough, greasy, skin‐coloured, or yellowish-brown papules are commonest on the seborrhoeic areas of the trunk, face, scalp margins, temples, ears, scalp, neck and flexures: the perineum, axillae and groin

 

 

  • Instead, Darier’s disease typically presents with greasy, hyperkeratotic papules, particularly in seborrheic areas, and may have some vesicles but not typically tense bullae.

 

Investigations:

 

Histopathology findings are:

 

  • ﻿Acantholysis - loss of cohesion between keratinocytes
  • ﻿Dyskeratosis - abnormal premature keratinization in the epidermis
  • ﻿Corps ronds- rounded dyskeratotic cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm in the epidermis
  • ﻿Corps grains - small cells with shrunken cytoplasm

 

 

  • DIF will be negative, as it is a Genetic condition but not an Autoimmune disease.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Oral retinoids are the mainstay of treatment of severe disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mutation of the ATP2A2 gene is seen in Darier’s disease.

 

  • This gene encodes the SERCA2 calcium pump in the endoplasmic reticulum, and mutations lead to abnormalities in skin cell adhesion and keratinization.

 

Option B. Corps ronds& Grains seen in histopathology

 

  • Corps ronds and grains are characteristic histopathological findings in Darier’s disease.

 

Option D. DIF will be negative in Darier’s disease,

 

  • It is not an autoimmune disorder but a genetic one.
  • Direct immunofluorescence is typically used to detect deposits of immunoreactants in tissue, which would not be present in Darier’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Darier’s disease, look for a genetic mutation in ATP2A2, histopathological features of corps ronds and grains, and expect negative DIF.
  • Tense bullae over flexors are not a feature of this condition and represent the incorrect statement in the options provided.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 66 Page No 66.1- 66.9

questions.text: A primigravida in her 3rd Trimester develops intensely itchy grouped vesicles in the periumbilical area. A diagnosis of Herpes gestation is made based on these features.  Which of the following is INCORRECT statement among the following options regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes Simplex Virus- 1 is responsible for Cross Reaction with Skin Antigens & Antibody Formation

 

Option B.

 

  • This is an incorrect statement. Despite its name, Herpes gestationis is not caused by Herpes simplex virus; it's a misnomer. The condition is autoimmune in nature

 

Herpes gestationis or pemphigoid gestationis

 

  • It is a variant of Bullous pemphigoid in pregnancy (NOT due to Herpes virus) and is associated with antibodies against BP-180 / BPAG-2.
  • The initial site of involvement is the periumbilical region.

 

 

  • It presents in the 2nd or 3rd trimesters with itchy, grouped vesicles (so Herpes word used in the name of the disease) in the periumbilical area that later spread to the abdomen, trunk, thighs.

 

Prognosis:

 

  • It flares in the intrapartum / Delivery period and tends to resolves spontaneously in the postpartum period.
  • Future outcome: It can recur in subsequent pregnancies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It resolves spontaneously in postpartum period

 

  • The condition resolves spontaneously in the postpartum period, although flare-ups can occur with menstruation or subsequent pregnancies.

 

Option C. Associated with antibodies against BP180 antigen

 

  • The condition is associated with antibodies against BP180 antigen, which is a hemidesmosomal protein involved in the structural integrity of the skin.

 

Option D. Variant of Bullous Pemphigoid

 

  • Pemphigoid Gestationis is considered a variant of Bullous Pemphigoid, occurring specifically during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigoid Gestationis, the autoimmune response targets BP180 antigen, and it is a pregnancy-related variant of Bullous Pemphigoid that typically resolves postpartum.
  • It is not related to Herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Ref: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology- 4th Edition Chapter 27 Page No 554

questions.text: An 84-year-old woman with a history of ischaemic heart disease is reviewed in the dermatology clinic. Her current medication includes aspirin, simvastatin, bisoprolol, ramipril and isosorbide mononitrate. She has developed tense blistering lesions on her legs as shown in the image below. Each lesion is around 1 to 3 cm in diameter and she reports that they are slightly pruritic. Examination of her mouth and vulva is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bullous Pemphigoid

 

Option D.

 

  • It is an autoimmune blistering disorder with antibodies against Hemidesmosomal proteins BP180 and BP230
  • that primarily affects older individuals and presents with tense blisters on the skin, often on the legs and arms.
  • Mucous membrane involvement is less common than in pemphigus.
  • Given the patient's age, clinical presentation, and medication history, bullous pemphigoid is the most likely diagnosis.
  • A skin biopsy and immunofluorescence testing can confirm the diagnosis.

 

Histopathology of Bullous Pemphigoid showing Subepidermal split:

 

 

  • mmunofluorescence shows IgG and C3 at the dermoepidermal junction in a Linear pattern.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pemphigus:

 

  • It is a group of autoimmune blistering disorders characterized by the formation of fragile blisters and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes.

 

 

  • It typically presents with flaccid blisters and is often associated with involvement of the mouth and mucous membranes, which are not mentioned in the patient's presentation.

 

Option B. Drug reaction to Aspirin

 

  • This can cause various skin reactions, including urticaria or fixed drug eruptions, but it is less likely to cause tense blistering lesions like those described in the case.

 

Option C. Epidermolysis Bullosa Simplex

 

  • This is a genetic disorder characterized by blistering of the skin and mucous membranes in response to minor trauma or friction.
  • It usually presents in childhood and is not typically associated with the development of tense blisters in an elderly patient without a previous history of the condition.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In an elderly patient with tense blistering lesions on the legs and a history of ischaemic heart disease, the most likely diagnosis is bullous pemphigoid

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.10

questions.text:
Arrange the following blistering diseases based on the level of separation (i.e. site where bulla is formed superficial to deep)

 

  1. Pemphigus Vulgaris
  2. Linear IgA Disease
  3. Bullous Pemphigoid
  4. Epidermolysis Bullosa Dystrophica
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1,3,2,4.

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Pemphigus vulgaris involves the superficial epidermis where the desmosomes are affected, leading to intraepidermal blisters due to loss of cell adhesion between keratinocytes.
  2. Bullous pemphigoid is deeper than pemphigus vulgaris, with separation occurring within the subepidermal zone due to autoantibodies against hemidesmosomes.
  3. Linear IgA disease also features a subepidermal blister but is typically grouped with other immunobullous disorders that have a similar level of separation as bullous pemphigoid; however, it is differentiated by its distinct immunopathological findings.
  4. Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophica is the deepest, with separation at the level of the dermis-epidermis junction or within the dermis, resulting in severe blistering and scarring.

 

Image depicting structure of DEJ / BMZ

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pathophysiology of blistering disorders, specifically Pemphigus vulgaris causes superficial blisters within the epidermis, bullous pemphigoid and linear IgA disease cause subepidermal blisters, and epidermolysis bullosa dystrophica involves the deepest level of separation within the dermis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.4-10

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 512

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presented with blisters and crusts all over the body. The Histopathology of the patient is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bullous Pemphigoid

 

Option A.

 

  • The histopathology image provided shows a subepidermal blister with a relatively cell-poor, inflammatory infiltrate in the dermis, which may contain some eosinophils.
  • Based on this finding and the clinical presentation, the most likely diagnosis is Bullous pemphigoid.

 

Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by the following features:

 

  • Subepidermal blistering
  • Tense bullae that do not rupture easily
  • Elderly patient population
  • Often has an eosinophil-rich infiltrate in the dermis

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis:

 

  • This condition typically presents with grouped vesicles as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • Histology usually shows neutrophilic infiltrates at the tips of dermal papillae, with granular IgA deposits found on direct immunofluorescence.

 

Option C. Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita:

 

  • This is a rare, chronic subepidermal blistering disease that usually presents as non-inflammatory blisters on trauma-prone areas, with an onset that can be at any age.
  • Histologically, it can resemble bullous pemphigoid but tends to have a more cell-poor infiltrate and is often associated with trauma.
  • Direct immunofluorescence shows IgG deposits at the basement membrane.

 

Option D. Pemphigus vulgaris:

 

  • This autoimmune condition presents with supra basal acantholysis leading to intra epidermal blisters.

 

 

  • Histopathology of Pemphigus vulgaris showing Row of TOMBSTONE appearance.
  • It is characterized by flaccid blisters and erosions, often starting in the oral mucosa, and a positive Nikolsky's sign.
  • Histopathology would show acantholytic keratinocytes above the basal layer of the epidermis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The characteristic histological features of bullous pemphigoid, include subepidermal blistering with a variable inflammatory infiltrate, often containing eosinophils, and its clinical presentation with tense blisters in an elderly patient, which is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.13

questions.text: A 30-year-old male had itchy papulovesicular lesions on elbows, knees & buttocks. Direct ImmunoFluorescence (DIF) showed granular IgA deposition at Dermoepidermal Junction (DEJ). What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermatitis Herpetiformis

 

Option B.

 

  • The most likely diagnosis for a 30-year-old male with itchy papulovesicular lesions on elbows, knees, and buttocks with granular IgA deposition at the Dermoepidermal Junction (DEJ) on Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF) is:

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis is characterized by:

 

  • Itchy, papulovesicular lesions
  • Commonly located on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees
  • Associated with celiac disease.
  • Granular IgA deposition at the DEJ on DIF

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid:

 

  • Typically presents with large, tense blisters in elderly patients and shows linear IgG and/or C3 deposition along the basement membrane zone on DIF, not granular IgA.

 

Option C. IgA pemphigus:

 

  • Presents with pustules and shows intercellular IgA deposits within the epidermis on DIF, not at the DEJ.

 

Option D. Linear IgA disease:

 

  • Characterized by blisters that can form an annular pattern and shows linear IgA deposition at the DEJ, but the clinical presentation and age of the patient are less typical for this diagnosis compared to dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

 

Image depicting Linear IgA disease showing Annular pattern of lesion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis typically presents with pruritic papulovesicular lesions on extensor surfaces and is associated with granular IgA deposits at the DEJ on DIF.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.54

questions.text: Match the following blistering disorders in Column A with Column B
questions.solution:
Ans.B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d

 

Correct matches:

 

 

Explanation:

 

  • Bulla spread sign: Refers to the extension of a blister to adjacent unblistered skin when pressure is put on the lateral border of the bulla as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • Nikolsky’s sign: On application of tangential pressure over skin on the border of an intact blister→ upper layers of epidermis separate from the lower layers →→skin peels off → extension of the blister.

→ Erosion formed →Nikolsky’s sign.

 

 

  • Bullous pemphigoid (BP) | c. Bulla spread sign + Nikolsky sign
    • Bullous pemphigoid (BP) typically does not exhibit the Nikolsky sign (as acantholysis is not associated with BP); the skin adjacent to the blisters is not easily dislodged by lateral pressure.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris | a. Bulla spread sign + Nikolsky sign + |
    • Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by both the bulla spread sign and the Nikolsky sign due to acantholysis within the epidermis.
  • Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome | b. Bulla spread sign - Nikolsky sign + |
    • Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) typically shows a positive Nikolsky sign, where the top layers of the skin slip away from the lower layers when rubbed.
  • Impetigo | d. Bulla spread sign - Nikolsky sign - |
    • Impetigo, particularly the bullous type, may present with blisters but does not typically show the Nikolsky sign or bulla spread sign.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid can be distinguished by the presence or absence of the Nikolsky sign, with pemphigus vulgaris being positive and bullous pemphigoid being negative for this clinical sign.
  • Additionally, understanding the typical presentations of Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome and Impetigo is essential for appropriate diagnosis and treatment.

 

Ref: Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.3, 115.13

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 499

questions.text: 30-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of persistent skin lesions that he describes as "dirty" and "warty". He mentions that these papules tend to cluster around his hairline, behind his ears, and on his chest and back, particularly in areas that seem to be rich in sebaceous glands. On examination, the papules are greasy, hyperkeratotic, and foul-smelling with some crusting. The patient also reports a family history of similar skin lesions. He is otherwise in good health and takes no medications. Based on the clinical presentation and family history, the most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Keratosis Follicularis

 

Option A.

 

  • This autosomal dominant condition, also known as Darier's disease, is characterized by keratotic papules that coalesce into plaques in seborrheic areas as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • They are often associated with a foul smell due to secondary infection. The presence of a family history supports this diagnosis.

 

Seborrheic areas over body:

 

  • Scalp
  • Forehead
  • Eyebrows
  • Eyelids (along the lash line)
  • Nasolabial folds (the lines from the nose to the corners of the mouth)
  • External ear canals
  • Postauricular (behind the ears) areas
  • Sternum (middle of the chest)

 

Dermatological Conditions presenting in Seborrheic areas:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Keratosis Pilaris:

 

  • This benign condition typically presents with small, rough bumps on the upper arms, thighs, or buttocks without a foul odour and is not generally found in seborrheic regions.

 

Option C. Pemphigus Foliaceous:

 

  • This autoimmune blistering disorder presents with superficial blisters that evolve into crusted erosions, not typically described as "dirty" or "warty".

 

Option D. Seborrheic Dermatitis:

 

  • It presents with scaly, flaky, and erythematous plaques in seborrheic areas but does not typically produce the warty papules described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presentation of Keratosis follicularis (Darier's disease) malodorous, greasy, hyperkeratotic papules in seborrheic areas, often with a positive family history, which distinguishes it from other keratotic and dermatologic conditions.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 66.3

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 944

choices.text: Bullous Pemphigoid
Dermatitis Herpetiformis
PUPPP
Pemphigoid Gestationis

questions.text: A 30-year-old female in her third trimester of pregnancy presents to the dermatology clinic with a 2-week history of itchy, tense blisters centralized on her abdomen, especially around the umbilical area. The blisters are on an erythematous base and she denies any prior history of similar lesions. She has no significant medical history and her pregnancy has been uneventful until these skin changes. Examination does not reveal involvement of the mucous membranes. Based on the clinical presentation, the most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigoid Gestationis

 

Option D.

 

Pemphigoid gestationis / Gestational pemphigoid / Herpes gestationis

 

  • This autoimmune blistering disorder occurs during pregnancy, typically in the second or third trimester, and is characterized by pruritic, tense blisters on the abdomen, often starting near the umbilicus.

 

 

  • It is associated with antibodies to BP180 and BP230, similar to bullous pemphigoid but is pregnancy specific.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid:

 

  • Incorrect because it typically affects older individuals and is not associated with pregnancy.

 

Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis:

 

  • Incorrect because this condition presents with grouped vesicles and intense pruritus, often on extensor surfaces, and is associated with celiac disease.

 

Option C. PUPPP (Pruritic Urticarial Papules and Plaques of Pregnancy):

 

  • Incorrect because PUPPP usually presents with urticarial papules and plaques, starts in the stretch marks of the abdomen, and typically does not involve the formation of blisters.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigoid gestationis is a pruritic, vesiculobullous disorder of pregnancy presenting with tense blisters around the umbilical area, typically occurring in the second or third trimester, without mucosal involvement.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 115.13

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 472

choices.text: Candidiasis
Erythrasma
Hailey Hailey Disease
Hidradenitis Suppurativa

questions.text: A 26-year-old presents with a chronic history of vesiculopustular eruptions, macerated plaques, and fissures predominantly in the axillary and inguinal regions. These lesions are recurrent and often exacerbate with heat and sweating. Physical examination reveals well-demarcated, moist, erythematous plaques with multiple small vesicles and superficial erosions. A skin biopsy is performed, which shows supra basal acantholysis with a “dilapidated brick wall” appearance without evidence of granulomas or significant dermal inflammation as shown in the image below. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hailey-Hailey Disease

 

Option C.

 

  • The histopathology image showing supra basal acantholysis and the “dilapidated brick wall” appearance of the epidermis is characteristic of Hailey-Hailey disease.

 

 

  • This autosomal dominant disorder typically presents in the second or third decade of life with lesions in the axilla and groin that flare with friction and heat.

 

 

Clinical image of Hailey Hailey disease

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Candidiasis:

 

  • Incorrect because while it can present with maceration and satellite pustules, the histology would show budding yeast and pseudohyphae.

 

Option B. Erythrasma:

 

  • Incorrect because it typically presents as well-demarcated pink to brown patches in the axilla and groin but lacks the histological feature of acantholysis.
  • It is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum and would fluoresce coral-red under Wood's lamp.

 

Option D. Hidradenitis suppurativa:

 

  • Incorrect because this chronic inflammatory condition presents with painful nodules, abscesses, and sinus tracts, primarily affecting apocrine gland-bearing skin.
  • Histopathology would show follicular occlusion and secondary inflammation, not acantholysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hailey-Hailey disease recognized by its clinical presentation of recurrent vesiculopustular lesions in intertriginous areas and histopathological findings of supra basal acantholysis, which is characteristic of the disorder.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 66.10

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 950

questions.text: A 90-year-old male presented with tense bullae, urticarial lesions all over body along with oral lesions. Which of the following statements is true regarding the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heals with Hypopigmentation

 

Option B.

 

  • A nonagenarian male presents with tense bullae and urticarial lesions across the body, including oral involvement. Given the details provided, the clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid, a subepidermal blistering disease.

 

Bullous pemphigoid:

 

  • While bullous pemphigoid often heals without significant scarring, it can leave behind post inflammatory pigmentary changes, including both hyper- and hypopigmentation.
  • Residual pigmentary changes can occur in the healing phase of bullous pemphigoid lesions, and oral involvement is observed in a subset of patients, supporting the choice of hypopigmentation as a correct statement about the disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dapsone is the treatment of choice:

 

  • Dapsone is not the first-line treatment for bullous pemphigoid; systemic corticosteroids and immunosuppressive agents are typically used.

 

Option C. Split is Intraepidermal at suprabasal level:

 

  • This description applies to pemphigus vulgaris, not bullous pemphigoid. Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by a subepidermal split at the level of Hemidesmosome & Lamina lucida as shown in the images below.

 

 

 

Image depicting Split at the level of Hemidesmosome & Lamina lucida in Bullous Pemphigoid.

 

 

 

Option D. Target antigen is BP 120:

 

  • The primary target antigens in bullous pemphigoid are BP180 (also known as BPAG2or type XVII collagen) and BP230, not BP120.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bullous pemphigoid can present with tense bullae and urticarial lesions, including oral mucosal involvement, and may heal with post inflammatory hyper- or hypo pigmentation.
  • The disease is characterized by a sub epidermal split with auto antibodies targeting BP180 and BP230.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.16

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 512

choices.text: Defect is in Calcium Pump ATP 2A2 Gene

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with a recurrent history of vesiculopustular macerated plaques over the axilla as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is TRUE about the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Histopathology Reveals Incomplete Acantholysis

 

Option B.

 

  • Histopathology reveals incomplete acantholysis: Correct.
  • The condition is likely Hailey-Hailey disease, also known as benign familial pemphigus.
  • Hailey-Hailey disease is characterized histologically by a "dilapidated brick wall" appearance due to incomplete acantholysis, where there is a loss of adhesion between individual keratinocytes within the epidermis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Defect is in the calcium pump ATP 2A2 gene

 

  • This statement is true for Darier's disease, not Hailey-Hailey disease.
  • Hailey-Hailey disease is caused by mutations in the ATP2C1 gene.

 

Option C. Nails have red & white longitudinal bands

 

  • This finding is associated with Darier's disease, not Hailey-Hailey disease.

 

Option D. Retinoids are the treatment of choice:

 

While systemic retinoids may be used in treatment, they are not the primary choice due to potential side effects and are generally considered when other treatments fail.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hailey-Hailey disease recognised by its clinical presentation of vesiculopustular, macerated plaques in intertriginous areas and its histopathological examination reveals incomplete acantholysis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 66.10

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with severe excoriations over the elbows, knees, and buttocks. Direct Immuno Fluorescence has IgA deposition in dermal papilla in granular pattern as shown in the image below. You have told the patient what the possible diagnosis for his clinical features could be and DIF findings. After learning about his condition, he googled, and now he wants to know which food he can eat safely. What would you recommend as a safe food item among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rice

 

Option B.

 

  • From the given Clinical findings of excoriations over extensor surface& the Direct ImmunoFluorescence showing Granular deposits of IgA, a diagnosis of Dermatitis herpetiformis can be made.
  • Rice is generally considered safe for individuals with celiac disease or gluten sensitivity, which may be associated with dermatitis herpetiformis, often linked to gluten intake.
  • Rice, Maize and Millets can be given.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Barley

 

  • Not recommended as it contains gluten.

 

Option C. Rye

 

  • Incorrect because rye also contains gluten.

 

Option D. Wheat

 

  • Not safe as it contains gluten.

 

 

Pathophysiology of Dermatitis herpetiformis

 

Acronym "BROW" helps to remember gluten containing foods:

 

  • B: Barley
  • R: Rye
  • O: Oats (not specifically labelled as gluten-free)
  • W: Wheat

 

Important Note:

 

  • Oats are inherently gluten-free, they are often contaminated with gluten from other grains during processing, unless they are specifically labeled as gluten-free.
  • Rice, Maize and Millets can be given.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Choose safe food options for patients with gluten-related skin conditions like Dermatitis herpetiformis, avoiding gluten-containing grains like barley, rye, and wheat.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.54

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple tense blisters over the body associated with pruritus. On histopathology neutrophils are visible. Which is the most likely antigen causative for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BPAG 180.

 

Option A.

 

  • In Linear IgA Bullous Dermatosis (LABD), the patient's immune system mistakenly produces antibodies against BPAG 180, a protein component of hemidesmosomes in the basement membrane of the skin.

 

 

  • Image depicting structure of DEJ / BMZ

 

 

 

  • This autoimmune response leads to the characteristic tense blisters seen in LABD.
  • Neutrophils can often be seen in histopathological examinations of LABD lesions.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. BPAG 230:

 

  • This antigen is associated with Bullous Pemphigoid, not LABD.

 

Option C. Collagen 7:

 

  • This antigen is related to Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita.

 

Option D. Desmoglein 3:

 

  • It is associated with Pemphigus Vulgaris.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • BPAG 180 is the target antigen in LABD, which presents with tense blisters and neutrophil infiltration on histopathology.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.33

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 323

Pemphigus Vulgaris

questions.text: A 65-year-old guy arrives with tense, itchy bullae over his limbs. The roof of the bullae collapsed after a few days. What is the most likely diagnosis shown in the clinical image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bullous Pemphigoid.

 

The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

 

Option A:

 

Bullous Pemphigoid:

 

  • Elderly aged people are usually affected.
  • It presents as tense itchy bulla, which do not rupture easily, which can have an erythematous base (urticarial wheals) & the roof of the bullae collapses after a few days forming settled bulla, autoantibodies (IgG) against BP180 (BPAG2) and BP 230 (BPAG1) antigens on hemidesmosomes are seen in these patients.
  • It is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.
  • Histopathology: subepidermal bullae with eosinophils
  • DIF: deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction in a linear pattern.
  • It is mainly treated with Topical corticosteroids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris:

 

  • This is another Autoimmune Blistering Disorder.
  • However, the blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are flaccid and easily ruptured as shown in the image below, as opposed to the tense bullae seen in bullous pemphigoid.
  • Additionally, the oral mucosa is frequently involved in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Option C. Dermatitis Herpetiformis:

 

  • This condition is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease) and presents with itchy papules, vesicles, and bullae.
  • However, the distribution is typically on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees as shown in the image below, and the appearance differs from what is shown in the image in the MCQ.

 

 

Option D. Linear IgA Dermatosis:

 

  • This is a rare autoimmune blistering disorder. The blisters are typically in a "string of pearls" or annular arrangement as shown in the image below,

 

 

 It's different from the presentation described and shown in the image.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • "Bullous Pemphigoid: It is a subepidermal blistering disorder predominantly affecting the elderly, characterized by tense itchy bullae, autoantibodies against BP180 and BP230, and eosinophilic involvement."

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50, Page No. 50.4-50.37.

choices.text: Rituximab
Dapsone
Cyclosporine
Azathioprine

questions.text: In the case of a child presenting to the OPD with tense bullae over the torso, and a biopsy of the lesion revealing subepidermal blistering and neutrophil infiltration, what is the preferred drug for treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dapsone

 

Option B.

 

  • The preferred medication to treat LIGA is dapsone.
  • It typically leads to rapid clinical improvement in CBDC
  • Dapsone, which primarily kills bacteria, also has an anti-inflammatory effect by reducing neutrophil enzyme activity.
  • As a result, it is effective in the management of LIGA.
  • Other options such as rituximab, cyclosporine, and azathioprine are reserved for cases that do not respond to dapsone or when dapsone is contraindicated.
  • A diagnosis of linear lgA disease (LIGA), or childhood chronic bullous disease is suggested by the clinical picture of tense blisters with sub epidermal separation and neutrophilic infiltration at the basement membrane in a child.
  • This is an auto immune blistering disorder that can clinically and histologically resemble bullous pemphigoid but is distinguished by linear deposits of IgA at the basement membrane zone.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rituximab:

 

  • This is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20 on B-cells and is used in a variety of autoimmune diseases, including those with blistering skin manifestations like pemphigus vulgaris.
  • It is not the first-line therapy for Linear IgA disease.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine:

 

  • This is an immunosuppressant that inhibits T-cell activation and is used in severe cases of many autoimmune disorders and in transplant patients.
  • It may be used in refractory cases of Linear IgA disease but is not the first choice due to potential side effects, especially in children.

 

Option D. Azathioprine:

 

  • This immunosuppressive agent is used as a steroid-sparing drug in various autoimmune conditions.
  • It is not the first-line treatment for Linear IgA disease and is considered in cases that are refractory to dapsone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The first-line treatment for LinearIgAdisease (ChronicBullousDisease of Childhood) is dapsone, due to its efficacy in managing conditions with neutrophilic infiltrates.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 989,998

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a clinical history of respiratory distress, persistent gastrointestinal symptoms, notable weight loss, and a duodenal biopsy revealing total villous atrophy and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, in conjunction with seropositivity for anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies, is most likely to exhibit which dermatological manifestation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dermatitis Herpetiformis

 

Option A.

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis

 

  • It is a blistering skin condition that commonly occurs in individuals with celiac disease, which aligns with the patient's gastrointestinal and serological findings.

 

 

Pathophysiology of Dermatitis herpetiformis

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Erythema Marginatum:

 

  • This type of rash is associated with rheumatic fever and not directly linked to celiac disease, or the antibodies indicated.

 

Option C. Erythema Multiforme:

 

  • While erythema multiforme can be associated with various triggers, including infections and medications, it is not specifically linked to celiac disease.

 

Option D. Malar Rash:

 

  • The malar rash is characteristic of systemic lupus erythematosus and is not typically seen in the context of celiac disease or dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis is the skin condition associated with celiac disease, characterized by blistering eruptions and confirmed by a positive anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody test.

Acyclovir
Steroids
Gluten Free Diet with Minerals & Vitamins

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with respiratory difficulty, chronic gastrointestinal issues, significant weight loss, and itchy papulovesicular lesions on her elbows, knees & buttocks. and a duodenal biopsy indicating complete loss of villi and a rise in intraepithelial lymphocytes. She also tests positive for anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Given these clinical features, which treatment would be most appropriate for her dermatological condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gluten-Free Diet with Minerals & Vitamins:

 

Option D.

Dermatitis Herpetiformis

  • The patient's symptoms and serological findings are consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis, which is a skin manifestation of celiac disease.
  • This condition is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease) and presents with itchy papules, vesicles, and bullae. However, the distribution is typically on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

  • The cornerstone of treatment for dermatitis herpetiformis is a strict gluten-free diet, which helps alleviate both gastrointestinal and dermatological symptoms.
  • Supplementing with minerals and vitamins is crucial due to malabsorption issues associated with celiac disease.

 

Acronym "BROW" helps to remember gluten containing foods:

  • B: Barley
  • R: Rye
  • O: Oats (not specifically labelled as gluten-free)
  • W: Wheat

 

Important Note

  • Oats are inherently gluten-free, they are often contaminated with gluten from other grains during processing, unless they are specifically labeled as gluten-free.
  • Rice, Maize and Millets can be given.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dapsone:

  • While dapsoneis used to provide rapid relief of itching and lesions in dermatitis herpetiformis, it is not curative, and a gluten-free diet remains the fundamental treatment.

Option B. Acyclovir:

  • This antiviral medication is not used in the treatment of dermatitis herpetiformis, as the condition is not caused by a virus.

Option C. Steroids:

  • Steroids may be used in the short term for their anti-inflammatory effects but do not address the underlying cause of dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis is the skin manifestation of celiac disease, characterized by pruritic papulovesicular lesions and granular IgA deposition at the dermo-epidermal junction, which is best managed with a gluten-free diet and supplementation with minerals and vitamins.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.54

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 532

questions.text: A person undergoing Anti PD1 immunotherapy (Nivolumab) presents with itching, eczema, and hives-like rashes. Upon histopathological analysis, a blister beneath the outer skin layer is observed. The direct immunofluorescence assessment of the affected areas indicates the presence of Linear C3 and IgG along the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bullous Pemphigoid

 

Option B.

  • The diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid is suggested by clinical presentation with history of Anti PD1 immunotherapy (Nivolumab) usage and confirmed by histopathology showing subepidermal blisters and direct immunofluorescence indicating linear C3 and IgG deposition along the basement membrane.

 

BULLOUS PEMPHIGOID (BP)

  • Immunobullous disease with a sub epidermal split
  • IgG is the autoantibody deposited.
  • Target protein: Hemi desmosomes
  • Target antigens: BPAG 2> 1
  • No acantholysis

 

Clinical Features of BP:

  • Involves primary lesions (Tense pruritic bullae on Erythematous skin or normal skin) and secondary lesions (Itchy Bullae → Erosions due to scratching).
  • Sites: Trunk, abdomen, flexural aspects of extremities, 10-30%of patients have oral erosions.

 

 

 

Investigations in BP:

 

  • Tzanck smear: Presence of eosinophils and Absence of acantholytic cells.
  • Histopathology of BP:

 

 

 

  • Direct Immunofluorescence of BP:

 

Shows IgG, C3linear deposits along Basement Membrane Zone.

 

 

  • Treatment of BP: Topical steroids

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • Is an autoimmune disorder that typically shows intraepidermal blisters and acantholysis.
  • Direct immunofluorescence usually reveals intercellular IgG and C3 deposition in the epidermis, not along the basement membrane.

 

Option C.Dermatitis herpetiformis

 

  • Is associated with celiac disease and is characterized by granular IgA deposits at the tips of the dermal papillae on direct immunofluorescence, not linear deposition along the basement membrane.
  • Dermatitis Herpetiformis showing Excoriations over extensors, Papulo vesicles as primary lesions & granular IgA deposits at the tips of the dermal papillae on direct immunofluorescence

 

Option D. Pemphigus foliaceous

  • Is another type of pemphigus which also shows intraepidermal blisters and acantholysis but affects the superficial epidermis producing Subcornealsplit.
  • The immunofluorescence pattern is similar to pemphigus vulgaris and not linear along the basement membrane.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid is suggested by clinical presentation and confirmed by histopathology showing subepidermal blisters and direct immunofluorescence indicating linear C3 and IgG deposition along the basement membrane.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 50.1-50.22, 50.52-50.55

questions.text: A male baby, born to a non-consanguineous couple, presents with blisters on areas of friction. Their previous baby also experienced similar issues and unfortunately passed away at the age of 2 weeks. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis Bullosa

 

Option A.

 

  • The male baby's current condition, characterized by blisters appearing in areas of friction, along with a similar history in a sibling, strongly suggests a diagnosis of a genetic condition called as epidermolysis bullosa congenita.

  • Epidermolysis bullosa is a mechano-bullous disease where blisters develop in response to mechanical trauma, often occurring in regions prone to friction such as the hands, feet, elbows, and knees.

  • Epidermolysis Bullosa has both Autosomal Dominant or Autosomal Recessive inheritance patterns.

  • The fact that the parents are non-consanguineous does not rule out a recessive genetic disorder, as both parents may still be asymptomatic carriers of the same mutated gene by chance.

    Why is non-consanguineous marriage mentioned when the disease is genetic?

  • Even in non-consanguineous marriages, autosomal recessive conditions can occur if both parents happen to be carriers of the same recessive mutation. 
  • While consanguinity increases the risk due to shared genetic background, non-consanguineous couples can still have children with genetic diseases, especially if the gene is more prevalent in a population (e.g., due to founder effect or carrier frequency).

 

 

  • Various types of Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) & Defects associated with them:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The likely diagnosis in a neonate presenting with blistering at areas of friction, especially with a similar family history and early demise in a sibling, is Epidermolysis bullosa, a genetic condition causing extremely fragile skin leading to blister formation with minimal trauma.

  • The fact that the parents are non-consanguineous does not rule out a recessive genetic disorder, as both parents may still be asymptomatic carriers of the same mutated gene by chance.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 71 Page no 71.4-71.16
